Award.AwardTitle: Moving beyond Subject Matter Knowledge: Assessing Elementary Teachers? Content Knowledge for Teaching Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop a better understanding about the key design features important for developing valid and reliable assessments of Content Knowledge for Teaching (CKT) science. The science education professional development landscape is full of a variety of learning opportunities to enhance K-12 science teachers' abilities to effectively support their students' learning. However, the field is hampered by a lack of valid and reliable assessments of science teachers' knowledge that can be used for making decisions about which aspects of teachers' knowledge should be the focus of these professional learning opportunities. This project will provide an important step towards building consensus in the field about the most productive approaches for developing assessments of elementary teachers' knowledge in order to inform ongoing professional development efforts in science. This study is poised to support efforts to develop indicators that can be used to monitor and improve elementary science teachers' learning in both teacher preparation and professional development settings.

The project is designed to build upon the robust evidentiary base for the importance of science teachers' practice-based knowledge, which suggests that it is important for the field to have measures that can assess not only teachers' subject matter knowledge, but also their knowledge about how to teach these subjects. This validation study concentrates on examining how two types of science measures -- practice-based CKT items and subject matter knowledge items -- assess distinct aspects of elementary teacher's knowledge and how these measures relate to other indicators of teachers' professional preparation and experience. This work directly addresses indicator 6 , teachers' science and mathematics content knowledge for teaching, of the National Research Council report Monitoring Progress Toward Successful K-12 Education: A Nation Advancing? The project will assess 150 grades 3-6 teachers with items developed to measure science CKT, followed by cognitive interviews of 24 of these teachers to explore the content validity of the items and explore the relationship among science CKT and other measures of teacher quality such as years of experience teaching, self-efficacy, and self-reported confidence in teaching particular concepts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the pressing problems in science education is identifying the critical areas of knowledge that science teachers need to know and learn to be effective practitioners. There has been extensive research investigating the work of teaching science to determine and describe what this professional knowledge base entails. More recently efforts in the field have turned towards developing assessments to measure the professional knowledge needed for teaching science. The research reported here targets this problem space and provides an important step towards identifying the most productive approaches for developing assessments of elementary teachers’ knowledge that can be used to inform ongoing professional development efforts in science. 

This NSF EAGER project, Moving beyond Subject Matter Knowledge: Assessing Elementary Teachers’ Content Knowledge for Teaching Science, focused on validating a design theory for assessing content knowledge for teaching (CKT) elementary science. The goal of this project was to develop a better understanding about the key design features important for developing valid and reliable assessments of CKT science. In order to accomplish this goal, the study was designed to: (1) investigate whether and how science items that situate assessment tasks in teaching practice target knowledge that is distinct from science teachers’ subject matter knowledge and (2) examine how these measures of science teachers’ knowledge relate to other indicators of teachers’ professional preparation and experience. In this study, our research team addressed the following research questions:

  1. Are there measurable differences in upper elementary science teachers’ practice-based CKT and their subject matter knowledge?
  2. Does the science knowledge and reasoning used by upper elementary teachers differ for practice-based CKT assessments and subject matter knowledge assessments?
  3. How do teachers’ performances on the practice-based CKT assessments and the subject matter knowledge assessments relate to other indicators of their professional preparation and experience?

All three questions were designed to contribute to validating a design theory for measures of CKT science. Validating a design theory for assessing CKT refers to testing the relationship between the CKT domain theory and the key characteristics of assessment tasks designed to represent this theoretical construct. As theorized, CKT goes beyond common content knowledge and includes forms of knowledge that are unique to the domain of teaching. In particular, this theory suggests that items designed to engage teachers in using their content knowledge to address authentic, practice-based tasks of teaching would function differently than items designed to assess teachers’ subject matter knowledge. This research focused on gathering evidence to determine whether teachers responded to the CKT assessment measures by using the domain knowledge theorized to be necessary, in this case their specialized, practice-based knowledge, and whether these measures related to relevant indicators of their professional preparation and experience.

Findings showed that there were moderate differences in teachers’ performances across the practice-based CKT and the subject matter knowledge measures within topics. On average, within each topic, teachers’ scores on the practice-based CKT scales were lower than their scores on the subject matter knowledge scales, suggesting that the practice-based CKT questions were more difficult. Findings from cognitive interviews also revealed that assessment items that are situated in teaching practice require teachers to go beyond just straight subject matter knowledge and draw upon other forms of knowledge for teaching science. A majority of the teachers who answered the practice-based CKT items correctly leveraged both the relevant subject matter knowledge and their specialized knowledge for teaching science to answer these questions. Most importantly, findings suggest that teachers were more likely to have difficulty with the content teaching aspects of the practice-based CKT items, as opposed to difficulty with the content, which precluded them from answering these items accurately. This finding strongly suggests that practice-based items require knowledge of both science content and science as it is encountered and applied in teaching the subject. Finally, findings showed that teachers who reported teaching specific science topics (e.g., ecosystems; matter and its interactions) for seven years or more had assessment scores in those topic areas that were significantly higher than teachers who had been teaching these topics for six or less years. This finding underscores the point that not only is much of science teacher knowledge topic specific but that science knowledge as it is used in topic specific teaching is precisely the kind of teacher knowledge that grows over time through teaching experience. Taken together, these findings suggest that it would be important for science teacher educators and professional development providers to attend to developing the full range of science teachers’ CKT.
